Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2008 08:35AM Lee27 wrote: Hi Pip...I am a triple neg as well. I've been down the same path.  Chemo/2 surgeries within 2 wks./rads.  I had 19nodes removed with 5 live ones after 6 rounds of strong chemo treatments every 3wks.  I like to think my cup is half full of blessings. Doing radiatian now. 21 down and only 10 more to go!;-)  Stay strong and focused.  You can do this. Lee in NC
Posts.Title: Cancer spreading to lymph nodes pippadoll Curlylocks

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2008 07:29PM - edited Jan 19, 2008 07:30PM by Lee27 Bluewillow and gang, I had the runny nose & dripping eyes--hairless--happen to me as well.:-)  I was in a minor car fender bender in a grocery store parking lot where a girl drove by and hit my car.  When the Police came, I had to 1st explain the runny nose and eyes to the Policemen as they looked at me strange...told them I was not on drugs but doing chemo and had to get out of the sun. Would that not have been a headline on the news if they had taken me to the Police station in error and found out I was a BC patient and nothing wrong with me.;-) Take care and buy those tissues.
Posts.Title: Taxol and runny/stuff nose??? bluewillow MCBaker

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2008 12:50PM - edited Jan 26, 2008 12:50PM by Lee27 Sorry you are not being treated in a positive way at work.  It takes all kinds to be jerks. I've been lucky to have a boss that has compassion.  His wife needs lungs, but they say she's too healthy now. Go figure.  I hope you work for a larger company...I'd check out your rights with your HR dept. I hate to say it but it is true for me...men are much better to work with as your boss. Women can sometimes be so bratty at times in those positions. Her actions sound like it is all fear. I've gained friends and lost others during this journey. My very best to you.
Posts.Title: Employer issue MegTX AnnNYC

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2007 12:06AM - edited Dec 30, 2007 12:09AM by Lee27 It has been some time since I went back to these boards to respond to Barbeqrn.  You wished me well...and it worked.;-)  I did have to return to a second surgery 2wks after the 1st lump for a clearer margerine.  I'm doing rads now...about half way there. Hope you are doing well.
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy shaunasmith Lee27

Posts.Content: May 13, 2010 11:45PM Lee27 wrote: Hi RedBarb, Saw your reference to Claritin and could not help but jump in. I'm 3yrs out this month.  When I had chemo, they also had me take Claritin--and a few others as a test--to keep some of the bone ache down. It worked for me! I took it a day after that Neulasta shot. Heck, I still use it from time to time. Especially when the rainy weather sets in. Some people purchased those chillo pillows. I just kept warm and cool pj's beside my bed for the hot flashes. They'll subside over time. Hang in there everyoody. Thinking of you all. Lee 27

Posts.Content: Oct 27, 2007 09:43PM - edited Oct 27, 2007 09:47PM by Lee27 Thank you for submitting your info.  This is my 1st time to the Boards. I shall have a lumpec this Monday.  I hope all goes well.  I was told I would only stay one night at the hospial as well.  Dr. said he would certainly send me home with pain pills to help me manage as well.

Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2007 08:59PM Lee27 wrote: Well, I had the lumpec...have to go back this Mon. for a 1 cm more good tissue.  Upper inside arm is so sore.  Hard to put a down by side without pain. Onc. Dr. is setting me up for PT next week.  Will be good to get more movement in that arm. I understand the person that said she felt like she'd been beat with a bat.;-)  Will the numbness in my armpit go away soon?
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy shaunasmith Lee27

Posts.Content: May 18, 2010 12:59AM Lee27 wrote: Hi All, I had Taxotere and my hair grew back. I bought a baby's hair brush and enjoyed seeing hair again to brush.  It came back in like baby's hair. I've had it cut several times since. 2007 was my chemo. I did have my nail beds darken, but my Onc approved me getting my nails painted. Nice little excuse to get them done and feel good about myself as well.  Hang in there all. Lee27
Posts.Title: May 2010 Chemo fotopet leftduetostupidmods

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2008 05:10AM Lee27 wrote: Hi, I too have my port in my chest wall.  At first I found myself being so careful.  Then, my surgeon told me to not worry about it and sleep on that side if I wanted.  Well, I've had chemo, surgery (2), and just finished rads last week.  My chemo Onc directed my surgeon to go ahead and remove my port.  What a surprize!  So, I shall have it removed in his office this Friday.  I hear they give you a local and it takes about a half an hour to take it out in his office.  Hope it does not give me too much discomfort afterwards. Chicken Little ;-)
Posts.Title: OOOWWWWWWW!!!! one2beamup thedudess

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2008 10:35PM Lee27 wrote: Hi Jump...My best to you.  Take your meds!!! It will be ok.  Also, I agree with the exercises.  My Chemo Onc also sent me to a Vodder P Therapist to get my range of motion back. Boy did it help.  Various simple stretch moves on the kitchen table were successful for me; along with other moves.  I was determined to get my arm up over my head.  I had to in order to do radiation.  Started yoga this week as well. It helps me focus.
